PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A note of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1921, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Days: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here (✓) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

[X] All questionnaires
[X] Pioneer health conditions
[X] Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
[X] Pioneer housing
[X] Pioneer education and churchwork
[X] Pioneer farming experiences

Preservation of Questionnaires:

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

   In charge of a retail boot and shoe shop.

   Ship to Quebec, train to Toronto. One week later
   to Duluth, St. Paul, Emerson, Winnipeg, Broadway,
   then by wagon and horse, north, crossing the Dauphin
   river at Colten, to Crescent Lake about km from Beaver.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way,
   meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement

   Going down the banks of the River, crossing on a ferry
   managed by an Indian named Nakapenee, going
   up the bank of the valley, camping by a fire at night,
   arriving the second day at "Crescent City".
   Mrs. John Atkey and two daughters came with us to
   meet her husband who had left Toronto in the early
   spring and had homesteaded at Crescent.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   At the town site of "Crescent City" on the N.E. & W.
   23-3-W. 2nd where the stone cairn now stands.
   In a tent at first, wintered in a house belonging to W.S. Eckardt, very cold.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? On the S. E. 20-23-3-W. 2nd.
   Entry was made for this land by my father before leaving.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
   Two years at Kamloops B.C. 1907 to 1910.
   On the old homestead till 1896 - to school at Saltcoats

   To high school at Regina winter of 1899.
   Taught summer school at Minerva S.D. 1898-99.
   Then married and lived on my homestead on S.W. 20-23-3-W. 2nd until 1942.

   as possible he bought a team of oxen and worked on his farm
   where he lived while working for the Company.
It was considered a great adventure.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stand out in your memory which you would like to record?
   Yes, such as working oxen, frozen crops, much hunting, the first house, breaking branches, mosquitoes, prairie fires, the lake going dry 1886 to 1895, lake filling up again, fishing again in the lake, Indian Rebellion of 1885, sickness of the Indians the first winter 1883-4, the first log house which fell down before completion, the second little log house 12x14, the third log house, dove tail corners 1879, the first picnic 1884 and the slow pace you rode your animals' back and lastly won, first school in a tent 1884, then in a log shack 1887, then the R.R. came to Saltcoast 1888-1890 instead of corn, and many other happenings.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Rev. Jockey (Methodist) was the first minister in 1884, but he came from Broadview only at long intervals. Later Methodist and Presbyterian students from Saltcoast held fairly regular services alternating weeks.

Travel was by oxen at first unless there was need for more speed in that case we went on foot. Later horses were much better especially horseback.

25. When was the first car used in the community? I think it was in 1914 that a neighbor had one—the first.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make? Our first car was a second-hand Model T Ford, about 1916.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   Saltcoats 12 m., Goykton 18 m.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   We still trade at these centers, but the modern cars, trucks or tractors make travel very different.

29. How often did you shop in the early days? At first to Broadview about twice a year. After 1888 about once in two weeks, sometimes once a month.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays? Some people did after about 1920, but we never acquired the habit.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   I think it was in the winter of 1894 that I worked two weeks for $300 for a man in Saltcoats. I drew 8 loads of wood and two loads of hay from Crescent to Saltcoats 14 m. With this $300 bought my first suit of clothes for $300 from J. Eaton of Toronto. For some years we sent away for probably about ¼ of our supplies, mostly dry goods, but later this amount has been reduced.

After a long and tedious journey we arrived at Broadview. A man and team of horses from Crescent met us there and we left early the following morning.

The first great event was going down the hill into the Valley of the Qu'Appelle. Of course we kids thought it a great picnic to run or walk behind the wagon. The wheels were chained together for the steepest parts of the descent and the road was very rough.

When we came to the river Nepapenele, the Indian ferry-man, pulled us across on an overgrown boat or barge, wagon, horses, and people all at once.

Going up the hill was quite different. We were allowed to walk again. Progress up the hill consisted of a number of spots. Some carried blocks to put behind the wheels at suitable places to give the horses a short rest. After much shouting, puffing, and laughing the top was reached. What a wonderful view to look back! Seemed as though some giant hand had scooped a huge ditch out of the level prairie.

Again the blessing of sleep, the great restorer, settled down on the tired family. But again it was broken, this time by the rumble of thunder and the flash of lightning. One of those sudden August storms rolled in from the west as though nature wished to show her anger at the intrusion into her solitude. The tent was lighted up like day by the flashes, thunder followed in quick succession, and rain fell in sheets.

A pool formed in part of the tent, father dug a hole and bailed water out of the tent. That is my first and most distinct memory of Crescent. Mother was in despair. "Well there be a flood?" Wolves last night and water tonight, what a country!

But finally the storm rumbled off into the distance and once again quietness reigned! The remainder of the pool soon sank into the sandy soil and rest and oblivion reigned over all.

It was all gone by morning, that is all but the drops of water glistening in the early sun and smelling so fresh and sweet that all hearts were soon full of gladness. "Oh what a beautiful morning!" Father took his old single barrel, muzzle loading, shot gun and soon came back with two prairie chickens. Very soon mother had them frying with some pork and onions and did they smell good! They did that, but they tasted better. Already the west was showing that it had compensations, if only we had adaptability to use them.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Many moved away before the first winter and more before the next. The hardships were too much for them and the prospects too far in the dim distance.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

There was practically no movement of people away from our district during the 1930's; in fact some brought cattle to winter here. We never had a crop failure.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My father was one of the first school trustees in 1887 and for many years after. Later I became Secretary-treasurer and later trustee for many years. Also a short time as councillor of the R.M. of Saltcoats.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

I was the first to have inspection for T.B. in cattle, had the first fully accredited was made chairman of an association formed to extend the T.B. area, addressed over 35 meetings and succeeded in having 11 R.M. added to the area, the largest addition at one time also started the Pure Breed Cattle sale at Yorkton and was President for some years. Am now Hon. Pres.

Crescent Lake has its name from being more or less in the shape of a Crescent.
Many moved away before the first winter and more before the next. The hardy ones remained in them and the prospect to far in the dim distance.

There was practically no movement of people away from our district during the 1930s, in fact home brought battle to winter here. However, had a crop failure.

My father was one of the first who started in 1877 and for many years after. Later he became Secretary-Treasurer and Water Trustee for many years also a short time as Overseer of the R.M. of Saltlakes.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

The first great step was the change from buffalo to cattle. Train-roads of cattle were shipped from here at one time. About 1900 grain farming became more general than ranching. Power machinery has taken the place of horse power in the last 15 or 20 years.

Minerals and oil will be very important features in the near future. This country had a great future coming up soon.
